content:
Diagnosis:
T3N1M0 squamous cell carcinoma of left oral tongue

Previous treatment:
Radical chemoradiotherapy commenced 15 January 2024
Cisplatin 100mg/m2 days 1, 22, 43
Radical radiotherapy 66Gy in 30 fractions

Current medications:
Ondansetron 8mg bd
Dexamethasone 4mg bd
Co-codamol 30/500mg qds
Benzydamine mouthwash

Current situation:
Week 5 of chemoradiotherapy

I reviewed [redacted name] today during week 5 of radical chemoradiotherapy. Unfortunately, his treatment course has been challenging with development of grade 3 oral mucositis requiring increased analgesia and temporary nasogastric feeding. He completed two cycles of cisplatin but the third cycle planned for today has been omitted due to deteriorating performance status and acute kidney injury (creatinine 156, baseline 82).

He describes severe pain on swallowing requiring regular morphine, and has lost 4kg over the past two weeks despite nutritional support. His voice is notably hoarse. Examination shows confluent mucositis affecting the oropharynx with thick secretions. There is marked radiation dermatitis (grade 2) affecting the anterior neck. The previously palpable left level 2 node has significantly decreased in size.

Despite these challenges, we have agreed to continue with radiotherapy to complete the prescribed course, with enhanced supportive care. I have arranged daily review by our specialist nurses and dietitian input. Blood tests show stable full blood count but rising creatinine at 156. Magnesium and potassium supplementation has been arranged.

The plan is to complete radiotherapy as scheduled on 23 February 2024, with consideration of admission if oral intake deteriorates further. Follow-up CT head and neck is booked for 6 weeks post-treatment, and we will review him weekly during recovery phase then at 6 weeks with imaging results.
